ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Dristi is Namchi based organisation and was established in 1996 and has been working in the field of Health, Environment and Education, Child & Women Rights as a non-profit , non- funding and secular Organisation.It has been Implementing Targetted Intervention Programme on HIV/AIDS among the Transport Workers and Migrant Labours of Namchi,Jorethang for 5 years and presently working on Female Sex Workers of Namchi, Jorethang and Gyalshing. Have worked under RCH Programme as FNGO in South Distrcit since 2001-2003 and presently recognised as MNGO for South District of Namchi. Project Clean Namchi is being implemented since 2004 with the objective of keeping Namchi and its surrounding clean by disposing garbages through collecting users fee. Project Green Namchi was implemented with the objective of keeping Namchi Green. Running 5 Creche Centres since 2007 and Condensed Course of Education for adult women of Jorethang since 2008. Organisation is also running its own primary level school Vidyasagar Educational Institute since 2002. Family Counselling Centre has been established since 2008. We are currently implementing Project CHILDLINE (1098) for children in need of care and protection along with a Short stay Home named Manjusha - a short stay home

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Providing free education and running school and hostel up to 10th standard. The target groups are tribal and children from very low income group from all over Sikkim. we have successfully completed 19 years of service and in the year 2002 our organisation was awarded National Award for Child Welfare by the Ministry of Human Resource Development Department of Women and Child Development, Government of India. Since 2005 over 236 children have completed their secondary examination successfully and there are 360 students presently studying including 3 projects (i.e. hostel for boys & girls). Our Founder Trustee Miss Keepu T.Lepcha was also conferred Padma Shree in the year 2009 for her social work.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: No Government grant was approved in the fiscal year 2014 - 2015. Received in March 2014 the Trust received Rs. 10 lakhs as 1st allotment of Rs. 20 lakhs approved by the Ministry of Culture for construction of a hostel facility for Khachoed Pema Woeling Ani Gompa. Balance Rs. 10 lakhs was received in January 2016. Most of the expenses of the Khachoed Pema Woeling Nunnery is met through private sponsors and through offerings received for various puja.

No new allocation was made in 2014-15 fiscal year. However, Trust received Rs. 10 lakhs as first allocation of the Rs. 20 lakhs approved in 2013-14 fiscal year for the construction of a hostel for the nuns of Khachoed Pema Woeling Ani Gompa. Balance Rs. 10 lakhs was received in January 2016. Funding for the Khachoed Pema Woeling nunnery comes most from local sponsors and from offerings for puja conducted by the nunnery.

No new allocation was made in 2014-15 fiscal year. However, Trust received Rs. 10 lakhs as first allocation of the Rs. 20 lakhs approved in 2013-14 fiscal year for the construction of a hostel for the nuns of Khachoed Pema Woeling Ani Gompa. Balance Rs. 10 lakhs was received in January 2016. Funding for the Khachoed Pema Woeling nunnery comes most from local sponsors and from offerings for puja conducted by the nunnery.

No new allocation was made in 2014-15 fiscal year. However, Trust received Rs. 10 lakhs as first allocation of the Rs. 20 lakhs approved in 2013-14 fiscal year for the construction of a hostel for the nuns of Khachoed Pema Woeling Ani Gompa. Balance Rs. 10 lakhs was received in January 2016. Funding for the Khachoed Pema Woeling nunnery comes most from local sponsors and from offerings for puja conducted by the nunnery.

Remaining Rs. 10 lakhs of the original Rs. 20 lakh allocation in 2013-14 fiscal year was received in January 2016. Total expenditure for the year was over Rs. 63 lakhs of which 59 lakhs was for the hostel construction. At the same the construction of a meditation retreat center also started. Aside from the Ministry of Culture grant, all the funding was from local sponsors.

Rs. 6 lakhs was received in March 17 as 1st tranche of the Rs. 12 lakhs approved for fiscal year 2016-17. Renovations work required in the kitchen, bathrooms have recently started after the monsoon rains. Training in English language and computer have also commenced. A Khenpo is also providing Buddhist philosophy education and meditation training to the nuns. Training in meditation is crucial for spiritual advancement of the nuns.

No fresh grant was approved or released during 2017-18 fiscal year. Education and training of nuns and renovation work initiated in 2017 were continued. Major renovation work carried out during the period included repair of 45 windows and 7 doors, conversion of basement rooms into kitchen and a dining room. Some furniture for the dining rooms were also made. In addition to the project expenditure, a little over Rs. 7 lakhs went towards completion of the Retreat Centre.

All the project activities were completed during the fiscal year. A major delay in implementation of this relatively small project was due to insufficient funds for purchase of a Bolero vehicle for the project. This was finally done in Feb. 2019 with borrowing from other sources. Other major project activities included the renovation of a meditation hall, purchase of a basic lap top and furniture for meditation room. Release of balance Rs. 6 lakhs sanctioned by MOC is now awaited.
Project just starting implementaiton

ngoList.actName: SIKKIM REGULATION OF SOCIETIES, ASSOCIATIONS AND OTHER VOLUNTARY ORGANIZATIONS ACT 2008
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The Centre has ritualistic and meditation faculties and monks are trained in theoretical and practical aspects of Buddhism. Under qualified Abbot and teachers, age old tradition of recitation, hymns and artistic works such as making butter sculpture, sand mandala are taught Centre conducts regular annual religious ceremonies and Summer Retreat for 49 days according to Vinaya Sutra. Occasionally higher Guru visits Centre and give teachings on Tantra, Sutra and Vinaya etc resident monks.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: This is the only Centre in Sikkim belonging to Sakyapa tradition of Tibetan Buddhism. The main purpose is to preserve age old tradition by giving education to young monks. We have more than 100 resident students studying ritualistic tradition of Buddhism particularly of Sakya. The students are given free education, boarding and food. They are mostly from a very poor family from Sikkim and other parts of India . They are taught Tibetan reading, writing and also English. Monks are all ordained.

The Centre is constructing dialectical faculty (Sheda) for its resident monks in addition to its existing ritualistic and meditation faculty. These are essential for both ritualistic, meditation and theoretical studies of Buddha Dharma such as logic, madhyamika, vinaya, abhidharma, sutra, grammar, poetry etc. The new construction will provide assembly hall, classrooms and required rooms for daily activities the resident monks. It also has library, conference hall and toilet facilities.

The Centre has not received any grant from both the Centre and State Government in 2015-16. The expenditure of the Centre is usually met from the ministerial services conducted by the senior monks and donations received from the local devotees. The devotees offer puja at the monastery and through this income the expenditure of the monastery is met.

The Centre has not received any grant from both the Centre and State Government in 2017-18. The expenditure of the Centre is usually met from the ministerial services conducted by the senior monks and donations received from the local devotees. The devotees offer puja at the monastery and through this income the expenditure of the monastery is met.

The Centre has not received any grant from both the Centre and State Government in 2018-19. The expenditure of the Centre is usually met from the ministerial services conducted by the senior monks and donations received from the local devotees. The devotees offer puja at the monastery and through this income the expenditure of the monastery is met. The State government has been approached for grant to complete the construction work.
